bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, June 29, [1900]

div1.p: Reed details recent happenings around the base in Cuba. He sends his love to family and friends.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, June 29, [1900]
div1.opener:
No. 8.
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
Camp Columbia,
Quemados,
Cuba,
June 29, 6.20 a.m.
My precious wifie:
div1.p:
You observe
that old Mr Mantee can get
up early in Cuba as well
as at Keewaydin- Out of bed
at 5.30 a.m. this morning, (5.30 a.m.
this morning, is good,) and first,
a most delicious shower-
bath- Say, lovie, dear, we
must have a shower-bath
at Keewaydin- Not one of
those overhead affairs,
but one that throws out
the spray in a curve, so
that one's head doesn't
get wet- A good bath of
this kind is the best prep-
aration for the day's work
imaginable- Then, secondly, a
nice new suit of underwear,
& here I sit writing to my
sweet lady, who in her sweet
letter of June 22nd (no.3) which
came, last evening, says, “I
enjoyed my stroll all around
the premises so much”- “All
around the premises” made
me smile broadly- I could
see you with trump at
your heels & Jacob perhaps
in the distance, taking in the
beauties of Keewaydin, while
darling little piano-player
sat and sketched the sunset!
of course with Tootsey-Wootsey
at her feet! So the chocolates
came in time to be enjoyed
by my sweet babies- I am
so glad of that- I hope that the
mistake I made of putting U.
S. postage stamps on my letters
instead of Cuban, till yesterday,
won't prevent you from get-
ting my letters as soon as you
otherwise would have done
so- I'm told that they will go
through alright, only that post-
age will have to be payed
again at the other end- But I
know that my wifie won't ob-
ject to doing that- I have Cuban
stamps now. I wouldn't have
you miss my letter written
on the Boat for anything.
Yesterday I went down to Ha-
vana and ordered two suits
of Crash made- They cost $6.00
a suit and are very cool and
pretty- The weather here doesn't
begin to be as warm as in
Washington in Summer- The
breezes, both day & night, are
simply indescribably delicious-
our mess is very good & the mess-
mates are Dr & Mrs. Stark, Drs
Lazaer, Porter, Pinto & Carroll,
with the funniest-looking heathen
Chinese Cook you ever saw!
Raspberries don't need any working,
except those planted, this spring-
They might have a little chopping.
Am glad to hear but not surprised,
that Jacob has been such a good
boy- Remember me always very
kindly to Mr Moore & Jacob- Tell
Cora “howdie”- & Carrie, too- Don't
mention butter-milk for supper again-
That Rabbit hopping under the hammock
was old Brer Rabbit, of course! Will
write to sweet Joy tomorrow- Love & kisses
for my precious babies-
